topic.name: Global Political Mastery
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Global Political Mastery in Geography

objectives.objective_text: Identify that maps change over time.
Name a country that didn't exist when grandma was born.
Identify the former Soviet Union.
Identify a 'City' as a place with many people and buildings.
Name New York, London, or Paris.
Identify iconic landmarks (Eiffel Tower, Big Ben).
Identify the ocean as belonging to everyone.
Name the water near the beach as belonging to that country.
Identify the difference between land and sea borders.
Identify the flag of my own country.
Name the colors in a famous flag (like the UK or Japan).
Identify the flags of the G7 nations.
Identify the flags of all major nations.
Identify the country where I live on a globe.
Name three other countries I have heard of.
Identify countries by their continent.
Identify all 195+ sovereign states on a blank political map.
Identify that countries can be friends.
Name the United Nations (UN) as a place where countries talk.
Identify the NATO logo.
Name the capital city of my country.
Identify a capital as the most important city for government.
Identify capitals that are not the biggest city (e.g., Ottawa vs. Toronto).
Recall that borders are lines on a map.
Observe old maps vs. new maps.
Recall that cities are busy places.
Observe pictures of skyscrapers.
Recall that ships sail on the sea.
Observe lines on a map in the water.
Observe that flags fly on flagpoles.
Recall that the world is made of many countries.
Observe that different countries have different names.
Recall that groups help each other.
Observe flags of many nations together.
Recall that the leader lives in the capital.
Observe a star symbol on a map for a capital.
Summarize how the US map changed as it grew.
Explain that wars can move borders.
Explain the breakup of Yugoslavia.
Defend the stability of natural borders vs. artificial lines.
Locate 20 major world cities on a map.
Explain why people live in cities (jobs, schools).
Explain the concept of a 'Megacity' (10 million+).
Defend the role of urbanization in economic development.
Summarize that countries own the water close to them.
Explain that 'International Waters' means the high seas.
Explain the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS).
Defend the freedom of navigation in international straits.
Color a flag correctly.
Explain the meaning of the stars or stripes on a familiar flag.
Sketch flags from memory.
Explain the difference between a flag and a coat of arms.
Master the identification of all world flags.
Defend the importance of national symbols for identity.
Locate the 50 largest countries by area on a map.
Spell the names of major countries correctly.
Group countries into regions (e.g., Scandinavia, the Balkans).
Explain what makes a state 'sovereign' (government, borders, recognition).
Defend the concept of the nation-state vs. globalism.
Summarize what the UN does (peacekeeping).
Explain what the European Union (EU) is.
Explain the difference between the UN and NATO.
Defend or critique the effectiveness of the UN Security Council.
Memorize the capitals of major world powers (e.g., London, Beijing, Moscow).
Match 50 countries to their capital cities.
Locate capitals on a map.
Memorize the capitals of all South American and European nations.
Explain the concept of a 'Primate City'.
Master the capitals of all 195+ sovereign nations.
Defend the strategic importance of specific capital locations.
Compare a map of Europe before and after WWI.
Analyze the 'Scramble for Africa' and its borders.
Interpret the partition of India and Pakistan.
Connect the fall of the Berlin Wall to the map of Europe.
Compare a capital city with a business city (e.g., Washington DC vs. NYC).
Analyze the difference between a political capital and an economic hub.
Interpret the location of cities near water (ports).
Connect the Silk Road to historic cities (Istanbul, Samarkand).
Compare fishing near home vs. fishing far away.
Analyze the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ - 200 miles).
Interpret the 'Territorial Waters' (12 miles).
Connect the South China Sea dispute to maritime law.
Compare flags that look similar (e.g., Australia and New Zealand).
Interpret the symbolism of colors (Red for revolution, Green for Islam).
Connect the 'Union Jack' to other flags (commonwealth).
Compare the size of the USA with other nations.
Connect colonial history to modern country borders in Africa.
Compare a country with an alliance.
Analyze the purpose of OPEC (oil prices).
Interpret the function of the African Union (AU).
Connect trade blocs (NAFTA/USMCA) to economy.
Interpret why capitals are located where they are (defense, trade).
Connect the capital city to the country's history.
Evaluate the concept of 'Irredentism' (reclaiming lost territory).
Evaluate the strategic importance of 'Alpha' global cities.
Evaluate the strategic importance of the Arctic sea lanes.
Evaluate the Pan-African and Pan-Slavic colors in flag design.
Evaluate the status of unrecognized states (e.g., Taiwan, Kosovo).
Evaluate the tension between national sovereignty and international cooperation.
Evaluate the decision of countries to move their capitals (e.g., Brazil, Indonesia).
Construct a sequence of maps showing the dissolution of empires.
Synthesize historical shifts to understand current border disputes.
Synthesize the cultural significance of cities like Jerusalem or Mecca.
Construct a map of disputed maritime boundaries.
Synthesize the relationship between EEZs and natural resources.
Synthesize the history of a nation with the evolution of its flag.
Construct a mental map of the world's political boundaries.
Synthesize current events by locating all involved nations immediately.
Construct a chart of major supranational organizations.
Synthesize the impact of ASEAN on Southeast Asian stability.
Synthesize knowledge of capitals with political news.
Construct a mental map of the global financial network of cities.
